1.1 Some Integral Theorems We begin with two theorems, which basically say that integrals behave as you’d expect them to. Theorem 1.1: (Additivity of the Integral) Let \(a<b\) and let \(f:[a,b] \to \mathbb{R}\) be bounded. For any \(c \in (a,b)\), \(f\) is integrable on \([a,b]\) if and only if \(f\) is integrable on \([a,c]\) and \([c,b].\) In this case \[\int_a^b f = \int_a^c f + \int_c^b f.\] ADD DIAGRAM IN HERE Theorem 1.2: (Linearity of the Integral) Let \(a<b\), \(\lambda \in \mathbb{R}\) and let \(f,g:[a,b] \to \mathbb{R}\) be integrable. Then \(f+g\) is integrable, with \[\int_a^b f+g = \int_a^b f + \int_a^b g,\] \(\lambda f\) is integrable, with \[\int_a^b \lambda f = \lambda \int_a^b f.\] Now is the time to bring some algebra into the mix. Since the zero function \(0:[a,b] \to \mathbb{R}\) given by \(0(x) = 0\) is integrable, this means that the set of integrable functions on \([a,b]\) is a vector subspace of the set of bounded functions on \([a,b]\). 1.1.1 Useful Results about \(\sup\) and \(\inf\). To prove the above two theorems, we need to know a bit about how the bounds of a sum of two bounded functions behave. The following results tell us exactly what we want! Proposition 1.3: For \(I \subseteq \mathbb{R}\) non-empty, \(\lambda \in \mathbb{R}\) and \(f,g:I \to \mathbb{R}\) bounded: \(\sup_{I}(f + g) \leq \sup_{I}f + \sup_{I}g\), \(\inf_{I}(f + g) \geq \inf_{I}f + \inf_{I}g\), If \(\lambda \geq 0\): \[\sup_{I}(\lambda f) = \lambda\sup_{I}f, \;\; \inf_{I}(\lambda f) = \lambda\inf_{I}f,\] If \(\lambda < 0\): \[\sup_{I}(\lambda f) = \lambda\inf_{I}f, \;\; \inf_{I}(\lambda f) = \lambda\sup_{I}f,\] 1.1.2 Some Other Useful Facts Using everything we’ve learned so far, we can state a few more facts about integrals! Proposition 1.4: If \(a<b\) and \(f,g:[a,b] \to \mathbb{R}\) are integrable, then: \(\int_a^a f = 0\) (This is by definition!) \(\int_b^a f := -\int_a^b f\) (This is also by definition!) The function \(f \cdot g\) is integrable (recall \((f\cdot g)(x) = f(x)g(x)\)) \(\lvert f \rvert\) is integrable, with \[\left\lvert\int_a^b f \right\rvert \leq \int_a^b \lvert f \rvert.\] It’s worth mentioning here that point 4 above is actually an analogue of the triangle inequality for integrals!

1.2 The Fundamental Theorem(s) of Calculus We’ve finally made it to the biggest theorems of the course, and this ties in everything done in the last 11 weeks! Despite usually being called the fundamental theorem of calculus (FTC), it actually encompasses two statements, which is why we state them separately below: Theorem 1.5: (Fundamental Theorem of Calculus I) Let \(a<b\) and \(I \subseteq \mathbb{R}\) be an open interval containing \([a,b]\). Let \(F:I \to \mathbb{R}\) be differentiable on \(I\), and let \(f:[a,b] \to \mathbb{R}\) be such that \(f(x) = F'(x) \;\; \forall x \in [a,b]\),1 \(f\) is integrable on \([a,b]\). Then \[\int_a^b f = F(b) - F(a).\] Theorem 1.6: (Fundamental Theorem of Calculus II) Let \(f:[a,b] \to \mathbb{R}\) be integrable, and define \(F;[a,b] \to \mathbb{R}\) via \[F(x) = \int_a^x f.\] Then \(F\) is continuous on \([a,b],\) and If \(f\) is continuous at \(c \in (a,b)\), then \(F\) is differentiable at \(c \in (a,b)\) with \(F'(c) = f(c).\) So, why all the hype for these theorems? The first theorem makes finding integrals much easier, as derivatives are (generally) nicer to deal with than Riemann sums! The second theorem here gives you existence of a primitive for \(f\), which you can apply the first theorem to! As a warning, if in Theorem 1.6 \(f\) is not continuous at \(c \in (a,b)\), \(F\) may still be differentiable at \(c\)! See Problem Sheet 11, Tutorial Question 1 for more details. This is the definition of \(F\) being a primitive for \(f\).↩︎

1.3 Integration Techniques To finish the lecture recap, it would be handy to have some theorems which back up some standard integration techniques. Turns out that we do! The first of these (in a fashion) ‘undoes’ the differential product rule. Theorem 1.7: (Integration By Parts) Let \(f,g:[a,b] \to \mathbb{R}\) be continuous. Suppose that \(F,G:[a,b] \to \mathbb{R}\) are continuous on \([a,b]\) and differentiable on \((a,b)\) with \(F'(x) = f(x)\) and \(G'(x) = g(x)\;\; \forall x \in (a,b).\) Then \[\int_a^b fG = F(b)G(b) - F(a)G(a) - \int_a^b Fg.\] And finally, the second of these can be seen as a way of ‘undoing’ the differential chain rule. Theorem 1.8: (Integration By Substitution) Let \(I \subseteq \mathbb{R}\) be a closed interval and let \(f:I \to \mathbb{R}\) be continuous on \(I\). Also, let \(J \subseteq \mathbb{R}\) be an open interval, and let \(u: J \to I\) be continuously differentiable2. Then, for \(a,b \in J\), \[\int_a^b (f \circ u) u' = \int_{u(a)}^{u(b)} f.\] This means that \(u\) is differentiable on \(J\), and that the derivative \(u'\) is continuous on \(J\). For interest, the set of all continuously differentiable functions from a set \(J\) is denoted by \(C^{1}(J)\).↩︎
